Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




INTRODUCTION



Greenman-Pedersen, Inc. (GPI) has prepared this Preliminary Design Report to assist the Town
of Stratham with the Master Plan that is currently being drafted by the sub-committee of the
Stratham Planning Board, the Town Center Committee. This report provides the Town of
Stratham with traffic volumes, operations, and potential roadway geometric improvements
within the "Town Center District," which consists of the Stratham Traffic Circle (NH Route 33
[Portsmouth Avenue]/NH Route 108 [College Road]) and the NH Route 33 intersection with
Winnicutt Road. The goal of this study is to address safety and intersection capacity needs within
the Town Center District with the development of conceptual alternatives and the evaluation of
the impacts of each alternative in terms of capacity, safety, right-of-way needs, and construction
and maintenance cost. The improvements measures identified within this report also maintain the
historic character of the Town Center District by improving pedestrian and bicycle mobility,
balanced with improving vehicular operations.




10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                 Page 1
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




EXISTING CONDITIONS



STUDY AREA


The Town Center District is bounded by the Stratham Traffic Circle (NH Route 33 and
NH Route 108) and extends northeasterly along NH Route 33 to the Winnicutt Road
intersection. The location of the Town Center District in relation to the surrounding roadways is
shown on the map on Figure 1. A description of each roadway and the geometric and traffic
control characteristics of each of these intersections are provided below, followed by
quantification of existing traffic volumes, accident history, vehicle speeds, vehicle
classifications, presence of pedestrian and bicycle facilities, and availability of public
transportation.


Roadways

NH Route 33 (Portsmouth Avenue)

NH Route 33 is an east-west, state-maintained roadway that begins in the City of Portsmouth to
the east and continues west to the Town of Stratham. NH Route 33 provides connections with
Interstate 95 (I-95) and U.S. Route 1 in Portsmouth; and NH Route 108 in Stratham. Within the
Stratham Town Center District, NH Route 33 provides one travel lane in each direction and is
approximately 40-feet wide consisting of 8 foot shoulders and 12 foot travel lanes. The posted
speed limit along NH Route 33 is 40 miles per hour (mph).

Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




NH Route 108 (College Road)

NH Route 108 is a north-south, state-maintained roadway that begins in the City of Rochester to
the north and continues south to the City of Haverhill, Massachusetts. NH Route 108 provides
connections to NH Routes 125/202A in Rochester; NH Route 236 in Somersworth;
NH Routes 4/9 and the Spaulding Turnpike (NH Route 16) in Dover; U.S. Route 4 in Durham;
NH Route 152 in Newmarket; NH Route 85 in Newfields; NH Route 33 in Stratham;
NH Routes 27/111/88/101 in Exeter; NH Route 150 in Kensington; NH Route 107 in East
Kingston; and MA Route 108 in Haverhill, Massachusetts.

South of the Stratham Traffic Circle traffic circle, NH Route 108 is approximately 47-feet wide
consisting of 4 foot shoulders, 12 foot travel lanes, and a 15 foot two-way left-turn lane
(TWLTL). North of the Stratham Traffic Circle, NH Route 108 is approximately 40-feet wide
consisting of 8 foot shoulders and 12 foot travel lanes. Within the Stratham Traffic Circle, the
number of travel lanes varies as well as the lane widths. Generally, the minimum travel lane
width is 11 feet with a minimum shoulder width of 4 feet. Within the Town Center District, the
posted speed limit along NH Route 108 is generally 40 mph.

Winnicutt Road

Winnicutt Road is an east-west roadway under the jurisdiction of the Town of Stratham.
Winnicutt Road begins in the Town of North Hampton (NH Route 151 [Post Road]) to the east
and continues to west to Stratham (NH Route 33). Winnicutt Road provides one travel in each
direction and is approximately 24 feet wide consisting of 1 foot shoulders and 11 foot travel
lanes. The posted speed limit along Winnicutt Road is 35 mph.


Intersections

Stratham Traffic Circle ­ NH Route 33 and NH Route 108

The Stratham Traffic Circle serves as the junction of NH Routes 3 and 108. The Stratham Traffic
Circle circulates in a one-way, counter-clockwise direction. NO PARKING signs are posted
within the Stratham Traffic Circle. Although there are currently no sidewalks or designated
bicycle paths provided within the Stratham Traffic Circle, existing shoulders are wide enough to
accommodate bicycle traffic. At the northern portion of the Stratham Traffic Circle,
NH Route 33 westbound joins with NH Route 108 northbound. The NH Route 33 westbound
approach enters into the Stratham Traffic Circle under free-flow conditions and consists of a 22-
foot wide travel lane with 9- to 14-foot wide shoulders. The NH Route 108 northbound approach
circulates within the Stratham Traffic Circle, consists of a 19-foot wide travel lane with 8- to 10-
foot wide shoulders, and is under YIELD-sign control. Beyond the intersection to the west
within a ±235 foot distance, the roadway consists of two 12-foot wide travel lanes with 11- to


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                   Page 3
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




12-foot wide shoulders that diverge with one lane exiting the Stratham Traffic Circle onto
NH Route 108 northbound and the other lane continuing to circulate within the Stratham Traffic
Circle. The posted speed limit along this section of the Stratham Traffic Circle is 30 mph. Land
uses in the vicinity of this section of the Stratham Traffic Circle consist of Piper's Landing
(142 Portsmouth Avenue), Frank's Furniture (145 Portsmouth Avenue), The Wingate Salon &
Spa (139 Portsmouth Avenue), Richard L. Zeff, M.D. P.A. Plastic & Cosmetic Surgery office
(137 Portsmouth Avenue), United States Post Office (2 College Road).

At the western portion of the Stratham Traffic Circle, NH Route 108 southbound joins with
NH Route 33 westbound. The NH Route 108 southbound approach enters into the Stratham
Traffic Circle under free-flow conditions and consists of a 12-foot wide travel lane with 6- to 11-
foot wide shoulders. The NH Route 33 westbound approach circulates within the Stratham
Traffic Circle, consists of a 13-foot wide travel lane with 6-foot wide shoulders, and is under
YIELD-sign control. Beyond the intersection to the south within a ±180 foot distance, the
roadway consists of two 12- to 16-foot wide travel lanes with 4- to 10-foot wide shoulders that
diverges with two lane exiting the Stratham Traffic Circle onto NH Route 108 southbound and
one lane continuing to circulate within the Stratham Traffic Circle. The posted speed limit along
this section of the Stratham Traffic Circle is 40 mph. Land uses in the vicinity of this section of
the Stratham Traffic Circle consist of Twice A Lady (127 Portsmouth Avenue), Collector's Eye
(132 Portsmouth Avenue), and residences (129 and 131 Portsmouth Avenue).

At the eastern portion of the Stratham Traffic Circle, NH Route 108 northbound joins with
NH Route 33 eastbound. The NH Route 108 northbound approach enters into the Stratham
Traffic Circle under free-flow conditions and consists of two 12-foot wide travel lanes with 4- to
12-foot wide shoulders. The NH Route 33 eastbound approach circulates within the Stratham
Traffic Circle, consists of a 16-foot wide travel lane with 6- to 11-foot wide shoulders, and is
under YIELD-sign control. Beyond the intersection to the north within a ±605 foot distance, the
roadway consists of two 11- to 12-foot wide travel lanes with 6- to 11-foot wide shoulders that
diverges with one lane exiting the Stratham Traffic Circle onto NH Route 33 eastbound and one
lane continuing to circulate within the Stratham Traffic Circle. The posted speed limit along this
section of the Stratham Traffic Circle is 40 mph. Land uses in the vicinity of this section of the
Stratham Traffic Circle consist of Collector's Eye (132 Portsmouth Avenue), Kevin Kin
Enterprises Company Inc. (140 Portsmouth Avenue), and Piper's Landing (142 Portsmouth
Avenue).

NH Route 33 at Winnicutt Road

NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road intersect to form a three-legged, unsignalized intersection.
The NH Route 33 approaches provide a 12-foot wide travel lane in each direction with 8- to 10-
foot wide shoulders. The Winnicutt Road approach provides a 12-foot wide travel lane with 2- to
6-foot wide shoulders. Directional flow along NH Route 33 and along Winnicutt Road is
separated by a double yellow centerline. There are currently no sidewalks or designated bicycle


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                  Page 4
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




paths provided within the vicinity of the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road intersection. The
posted speed limit along NH Route 33 is 40 mph and along Winnicutt Road is 35 mph. Land
uses in the vicinity of the intersection consist of Stratham Historical Society (158 Portsmouth
Avenue), Ocean Bank (160 Portsmouth Avenue), residences (159 Portsmouth Avenue), Marco's
Pizza/NextChoice/Jeffrey L. Stern, DDS Family Dentistry/Law Office of Eugene A. DiMariano,
Jr., Esquire/Stratham Village Market (157 Portsmouth Avenue), and Stratham Fire Department
(4 Winnicutt Road).



TRAFFIC VOLUMES


Base traffic conditions within the study area were developed by conducting automatic traffic
recorder (ATR) counts, manual turning movement counts (TMCs), and vehicle classification
counts within the study area. The ATR counts were conducted along NH Route 33 east of the
Stratham Traffic Circle, NH Route 108 north and south of the Stratham Traffic Circle,
NH Route 108 within the northern portion of the Stratham Traffic Circle, and Winnicutt Road
east of NH Route 33 between Wednesday, August 25, 2010, and Saturday, August 28, 2010. The
TMCs and vehicle classification counts were performed during the weekday AM peak period
(7:00 to 9:00 AM), the weekday PM peak period (4:00 to 6:00 PM), and the Saturday midday
peak period (11:00 AM to 2:00 PM) on Tuesday, August 24, 2010, and on Saturday, August 28,
2010. All traffic-count data are provided in the Appendix.

Traffic on a given roadway typically fluctuates throughout the year depending on the area and
the type of roadway. Based on New Hampshire Department of Transportation (NHDOT)
guidelines for a traffic study, existing traffic volumes must represent the peak of the monthly
average peak-hour conditions. To determine if the traffic-count data needed to be adjusted to
account for this fluctuation, seasonal adjustment and historical count data provided by the
NHDOT were reviewed1 and coordination efforts were made with the NHDOT Bureau of Traffic
and the Rockingham Planning Commission (RPC). This information revealed that traffic
volumes in the month of August represent the peak month in the study area for the weekday and
Saturday daily periods, as well as with the weekday PM and Saturday midday peak hours.
Therefore, no seasonal adjustment was applied to the traffic counts for these time periods.
Traffic volumes in the month of August are 6.7 percent lower than peak-month volumes during
the weekday AM. Therefore, the weekday AM peak hour traffic volumes were increased by
1.6 percent to represent 2010 peak-month traffic volumes. The NHDOT seasonal adjustment
data are provided in the Appendix.



1   New Hampshire Department of Transportation Automatic Traffic Recorder Report, Route 108 west of Bunker Hill
    Road, Stratham, NH, 2005.

ACCIDENTS


Accident data for the study area intersections were obtained from the Stratham Police
Department for between January 1, 2007 and September 22, 2010. A summary of the accident
data at the study area intersections is provided in Table 2.

The intersections within the Stratham Traffic Circle have experienced 17 reported collisions over
the time period studied (3 years, 8 months, and 22 days), averaging less than 5 incidents per
year. Of these reported collisions, approximately 82 percent (14 out of 17) involved property
damage only and approximately 76 percent (13 out of 17) were identified as rear-end collisions.
Approximately 47 percent (8 out of 17) of the reported incidents occurred during weekday peak
commuter hours and approximately 35 percent (6 out of 17) occurred during inclement weather
conditions. No fatalities were reported within the Stratham Traffic Circle during the time period
studied. Within traffic circles, rotaries, or roundabouts, collisions typically occur when a
motorist is entering or leaving the circular roadway. The severity of the reported incidents is
typical of traffic circles because vehicles all travel in the same direction and most crashes are
glancing blows at low angles of impact.

The NH Route 33 intersection with Winnicutt Road has experienced a total of 9 reported
collisions over the time period studied (3 years, 8 months, and 22 days), averaging just over
2 incidents per year. Of these reported collisions, approximately 67 percent (6 out of 9) involved
property damage only and approximately 67 percent (6 out of 9) were identified as either rear-
end or head-on collisions. Approximately 22 percent (2 out of 9) occurred during the weekday
peak commuting hours and 11 percent (1 out of 9) occurred during inclement weather conditions.
No fatalities were reported at the NH Route 33 intersection with Winnicutt Road during the time
period studied. The number of reported accidents is not significant and the severity is low, so
safety of the intersection is not reflected in the Stratham Police Department accident data.

VEHICLE SPEEDS


Speed measurements were conducted within the Statham Town Center District by measuring the
elapsed time for vehicles traveling a short, pre-measured distance between two checkpoints. The
travel time was recorded using ATR's over a 24-hour period, thereby also recording travel
speeds during non-peak hours when vehicle speeds are not affected by platooning. Dividing the
elapsed time by the measured distance between checkpoints derives the speed. The observed
speeds are summarized in Table 3 and all data are provided in the Appendix.


                 Table 3
                 OBSERVED TRAVEL SPEEDS


                                                                             Posted      Average   85th Percentile
                                      Location/Direction                   Speed Limit   Speed a       Speed b

                     NH Route 33 northeast of Traffic Circle:
                        Eastbound                                                  40       36           43
                        Westbound                                                  40       39           45

                     NH Route 108 north of Traffic Circle:
                        Northbound                                                 45       38           43
                        Southbound                                                 40       42           48

                     NH Route 108 south of Traffic Circle:
                        Northbound                                                 40       43           47
                        Southbound                                                 40       44           49

                     NH Route 108 within northern
                     portion of Traffic Circle:
                         Westbound                                                 30       36           40

                     Winnicutt Road east of NH Route 33:
                        Eastbound                                                  35       33           39
                        Westbound                                                  35       32           39

                 a
                     Average speed.
                 b
                     Speed at or below which 85 percent of traffic is traveling.



As shown in Table 3, average speeds along NH Route 33 east of the Stratham Traffic Circle
were observed to be generally consistent with the posted speed limit and the 85th percentile
speeds were observed to be higher than the posted speed limit. Speeds along NH Route 108
north of the Stratham Traffic Circle in the northbound direction (departing the Traffic Circle)


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                                           Page 9
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




were observed to be lower than the posted speed limit and higher in the southbound direction
(approaching the Traffic Circle). Speeds along NH Route 108 south of the Stratham Traffic
Circle were observed to be higher than the posted speed limit. Within the northern portion of the
Stratham Traffic Circle between NH Routes 33 and 108, speeds were observed to be higher than
the posted speed limit. Reasons for the higher speeds at some of the locations may be due to the
horizontal and vertical alignments of the roadways approaching and departing the Stratham
Traffic Circle. In addition, the Stratham Traffic Circle entering roadways are under free-flow
control while the internal circulating movements are under YIELD-sign control, which is in
contrast to standard rotaries or roundabouts where the entering maneuvers are under YIELD-sign
control.

Speeds along Winnicutt Road were observed to be generally consistent with the posted speed
limit. A possible reason for the consistency between the observed and posted speeds may be due
to the presence of the School Zone signs (S1-1) along Winnicutt Road as well as the new
Stratham Fire Department at 4 Winnicutt Road.



VEHICLE CLASSIFICATION


A vehicle classification survey was conducted within the Statham Town Center District in
conjunction with traffic counts and vehicle speed counts. A summary of the vehicle classification
observations is shown in Table 4. These results show that the volume of traffic within the
vicinity and including the Stratham Traffic Circle currently consists of approximately 2 percent
bicycles, 77 percent passenger cars, 20 percent of heavy vehicles with two axles, and 1 percent
of heavy vehicles with three axles or more. Along Winnicutt Road, the volume of traffic consists
of 3 percent bicycles, 75 percent passenger cars, 21 percent of heavy vehicles with two axles,
and 1 percent of heavy vehicles with three axles or more. The survey data are provided in the
Appendix.

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION


The Cooperative Alliance for Seacoast Transportation (COAST) provides bus service in
Stratham. Bus Route 7 begins in Newington at Fox Run Mall; stops at Portsmouth
Transportation Center, at Great Bay Community College in Stratham, at Downtown Gazebo in
Newmarket, and in at King's Plaza Stratham; and ends at Exeter Train Station. Although Bus
Route 7 travels along NH Route 108, there are no stops within the Stratham Town Center
District.




10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                        Page 12
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




FUTURE CONDITIONS



A 20 year planning horizon was selected for this Preliminary Design Report. Traffic volumes on
the roadway network at this time will include existing traffic and new traffic due to normal traffic
growth. Consideration of these factors resulted in the development of 2030 Design Year traffic
volumes.



TRAFFIC GROWTH


To develop the Design Year forecast volumes, an annual average traffic-growth percentage was
determined based on NHDOT and RPC historical traffic-volume data. The NHDOT data
revealed that there has been a 0.65 percent decrease in traffic between 2002 and 2008 in the
Town of Stratham. In the region, however, NHDOT expects traffic volumes to increase by
0.92 percent per year over the next 10 to 20 years. The region-wide growth rate of vehicle miles
traveled as estimated with the RPC model for an air quality conformity analysis was determined
to be 0.73 percent per year. Within Stratham, the RPC regional travel demand model suggests an
average annualized growth rate of 0.28 percent between 2012 and 2026 and 0.60 percent
between 2026 and 2035. Therefore, to provide a conservative (worse than expected) basis for the
analysis, a 1.0 percent compounded annual growth rate was assumed to account for general
population growth and the traffic generated by smaller area developments.

Based on discussions with officials from the Town of Stratham, RPC, and NHDOT, there are no
planned roadway improvement measures to be implemented within the Stratham Town Center
District during the design horizon.




10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                               Page 13
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




DESIGN YEAR TRAFFIC VOLUMES


The 2030 Design Year traffic volumes were developed by applying a total growth of
22.0 percent (1.0 percent compounded annually over 20 years) to the 2010 Existing traffic
volumes. The 2030 Design Year peak-hour traffic-flow networks are shown on Figures 5
through 7 for the weekday AM, weekday PM and Saturday midday peak hours, respectively.



TRAFFIC INCREASES


The existing traffic volumes on the study area roadways and traffic volumes anticipated in 2030
based on general-population growth are summarized in Table 5. With the additional growth
anticipated over the next 20 years, traffic volumes are anticipated to increase by approximately
22 percent.

Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




INTERSECTION ANALYSES



CAPACITY ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY


A primary result of capacity analysis is the assignment of levels of service to traffic facilities
under various traffic-flow conditions. The capacity analysis methodology is based on the
concepts and procedures in the Highway Capacity Manual (HCM).2 The concept of level of
service (LOS) is defined as a qualitative measure describing operational conditions within a
traffic stream and their perception by motorists and/or passengers. A level-of-service definition
provides an index to quality of traffic flow in terms of such factors as speed, travel time, freedom
to maneuver, traffic interruptions, comfort, convenience, and safety.

Six levels of service are defined for each type of facility. They are given letter designations from
A to F, with LOS A representing the best operating conditions and LOS F the worst. Since the
level of service of a traffic facility is a function of the traffic flows placed upon it, such a facility
may operate at a wide range of levels of service, depending on the time of day, day of week, or
period of year. A description of the operating condition under each level of service is provided
below:

·     LOS A describes conditions with little to no delay to motorists.

·     LOS B represents a desirable level with relatively low delay to motorists.

·     LOS C describes conditions with average delays to motorists.



2Highway        Capacity Manual 2000, Transportation Research Board; Washington, D.C.; 2000.


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                      Page 15
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




·     LOS D describes operations where the influence of congestion becomes more noticeable.
      Delays are still within an acceptable range.

·     LOS E represents operating conditions with high delay values. This level is considered by
      many agencies to be the limit of acceptable delay.

·     LOS F is considered to be unacceptable to most drivers with high delay values that often
      occur, when arrival flow rates exceed the capacity of the intersection.


Unsignalized Intersections

Levels of service for unsignalized intersections are calculated using the operational analysis
methodology of the HCM. The procedure accounts for lane configuration on both the minor and
major street approaches, conflicting traffic stream volumes, and the type of intersection control
(STOP, YIELD, or all-way STOP control). The definition of level of service for unsignalized
intersections is a function of average control delay. Control delay includes initial deceleration
delay, queue move-up time, stopped delay, and final acceleration delay. The level-of-service
criteria for unsignalized intersections are shown in Table 6.


Signalized Intersections

Levels of service for signalized intersections are also calculated using the operational analysis
methodology of the HCM. The methodology for signalized intersections assesses the effects of
signal type, timing, phasing, and progression; vehicle mix; and geometrics on average control
delay. Control delay includes initial deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped delay, and
final acceleration delay. Table 6 summarizes the relationship between level of service and
average control delay.




10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                               Page 16
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




                  Table 6
                  LEVEL-OF-SERVICE CRITERIA FOR INTERSECTIONS


                                             Unsignalized Intersection Criteria   Signalized Intersection Criteria
                        Level of                  Average Control Delay               Average Control Delay
                        Service                    (Seconds per Vehicle)               (Seconds per Vehicle)

                              A                               10                                   10
                              B                       >10 and 15                           >10 and 20
                              C                       >15 and 25                           >20 and 35
                              D                       >25 and 35                           >35 and 55
                              E                       >35 and 50                           >55 and 80
                              F                               >50                                  >80

                  Source: Highway Capacity Manual 2000, Transportation Research Board; Washington, D.C.; 2000.
                          Pages 10-16 and 17-2.



For signalized intersections, this delay criterion may be applied in assigning level-of-service
designations to individual lane groups, to individual intersection approaches, or to the entire
intersection. For unsignalized intersections, this delay criterion may be applied in assigning
level-of-service designations to individual lane groups or to individual intersection approaches.



QUEUE ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY


For signalized intersections, the maximum back of queue during a typical (average) signal cycle
and a 95th percentile signal cycle were calculated for each lane group during the peak periods
studied. The back of queue is the length of a backup of vehicles from the stop line of a signalized
intersection to the last vehicle in the queue that is required to stop, regardless of the signal
indication. The length of this queue depends on a number of factors including signal timing,
vehicle arrival patterns, and the saturation flow rate.

For unsignalized intersections, the 95th percentile queue represents the length of queue of the
critical minor-street movement that is not expected to be exceeded 95 percent of the time during
the analysis period (typically one hour). In this case, the queue length is a function of the
capacity of the movement and the movement's degree of saturation.




10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                                           Page 17
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




CAPACITY AND QUEUE ANALYSIS RESULTS


The study area intersections have been analyzed through application of the procedures described
above. The capacity and queue analyses were conducted at the study locations under
2010 Existing and 2030 Design Year conditions for the weekday AM, weekday PM and
Saturday midday peak hours. The level-of-service and queue analysis results are discussed below
and presented in Table 7. All analysis worksheets are provided in the Appendix.


Stratham Traffic Circle ­ NH Route 33 and NH Route 108

Northern Section ­ NH Route 33 Westbound and NH Route 108 Northbound

At the northern portion of the Stratham Traffic Circle, turns from within the Stratham Traffic
Circle (NH Route 108 northbound) at the junction with NH Route 33 westbound currently
operate with long delays (LOS F) and queues during the weekday PM and Saturday midday peak
hours. Under 2030 Design Year conditions, the capacity constraints on this approach are
expected to be exacerbated with the addition of historical traffic growth. The NH Route 33
westbound entering approach is under free-flow control and operates at optimal levels (LOS A)
under existing and design-year conditions.

Western Section ­ NH Route 108 Southbound and NH Route 33 Westbound

At the western portion of the Stratham Traffic Circle, turns from within the Stratham Traffic
Circle (NH Route 33 westbound) at the junction with NH Route 108 southbound currently
operate with long delays (LOS F) and queues during the weekday AM, weekday PM, and
Saturday midday peak hours. Under 2030 Design Year conditions, the capacity constraints on
this approach are expected to be exacerbated with the addition of historical traffic growth. The
NH Route 108 southbound entering approach is under free-flow control and operates at optimal
levels (LOS A) under existing and design-year conditions.

Eastern Section ­ NH Route 108 Northbound and NH Route 33 Eastbound

At the eastern portion of the Stratham Traffic Circle, turns from within the Stratham Traffic
Circle (NH Route 33 eastbound) at the junction with NH Route 108 northbound currently
operate with desirable service levels (LOS C or better) and minimal queuing during the
weekday AM, weekday PM, and Saturday midday peak hours. Under 2030 Design Year
conditions, this approach is expected to operate at acceptable levels (LOS D or better) with
minimal queuing during the time periods evaluated. The NH Route 108 northbound entering
approach is under free-flow control and operates at optimal levels (LOS A) under existing and
design-year conditions.


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                              Page 18
    PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
    Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




    NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road

    Under 2010 Existing traffic-volume conditions, the Winnicutt Road approach to NH Route 33
    currently operates at acceptable service levels (LOS D) during the weekday AM and
    weekday PM peak hours, but with long delays (LOS F) during the Saturday midday peak hour.
    Under 2030 Design Year traffic-volume conditions, the Winnicutt Road approach to
    NH Route 33 is expected to experience long delays (LOS F) and queuing with the addition of
    historical traffic growth. The NH Route 33 northbound and southbound approaches operate with
    minimal delay (LOS A) and queues under existing and design-year conditions during the time
    periods evaluated.

IMPROVEMENT ALTERNATIVES



Based on field observations, discussions with local and state officials, and as demonstrated by
the capacity and queue analysis presented in the Capacity and Queue Analysis Results section of
this report, the Stratham Town Center District intersections are currently operating at or are
expected to operate at capacity. With additional traffic growth expected over the next 20 years,
operational deficiencies are anticipated to be further exacerbated. Therefore, alternative
measures to improve traffic operations in the future have been developed.

Based on coordination efforts with the Stratham Town Center Committee there is a strong desire
to develop a "village" character of downtown to provide opportunities for shopping, doing
business, recreation, and gathering, In addition, concern has been expressed that pedestrian and
bicycle travel in the Stratham Town Center District is very difficult. Several roadway
improvement alternatives were developed that attempt to balance the needs of commuters and
residents by creating a more traversable Town Center District for vehicles, pedestrians, and
bicycles; improve traffic operations and safety along the corridor; and improve the aesthetic
quality of the Town Center. The following sections detail the improvement alternatives that have
been evaluated.



NH ROUTE 33 AT WINNICUTT ROAD


Alternative 1 ­ Geometric Improvements

As described in the Accidents section of this report, the NH Route 33 intersection with Winnicutt
Road has experienced an average of just over 2 reported incidents per year with 33 percent (3 out
of 9) resulting in personal injury. To reduce the frequency and severity of vehicular conflicts at


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                               Page 21
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




the intersection and to reduce the frequency and severity of intersection incidents, the first
improvement alternative evaluated for the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road intersection
involved geometric design improvements. Based on an evaluation of exclusive turn lane warrants
along NH Route 33 at Winnicutt Road, the NH Route 33 northbound approach exceeds the
thresholds for an exclusive right-turn lane under the existing traffic-volume conditions during all
three critical time periods and the southbound approach only exceeds the thresholds for an
exclusive left-turn lane during the Saturday midday peak hour.3,4 Therefore, vehicular conflicts
can be reduced by separating the NH Route 33 northbound right turns and through movements at
the intersection. It is not recommended that the Winnicutt Road approach be widened to provide
exclusive turn lanes due to the low volume of Winnicutt Road right-turning vehicles and due to
the limited sight distance that could occur if a heavy vehicle was turning left simultaneously with
a passenger vehicle turning right onto NH Route 33.

In addition, driveway access at or near unsignalized intersections may confuse motorists using
the intersection and create vehicular conflicts. For good access management practice,
consideration should be given to closing, relocating, or restricting driveways within 250 feet of
an intersection. The existing building at 159 Portsmouth Avenue has two driveways that connect
on the east and west sides of the building. It is recommended that the southwestern-most
driveway located within ±50 feet of the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road intersection be closed
and the northeastern-most driveway be maintained for motorists destined to or originating from
159 Portsmouth Avenue. A conceptual roadway sketch for this alternative is included on
Figure 8.

As shown in Table 8, capacity and queue analyses were conducted at the NH Route 33 and
Winnicutt Road intersection for the 2030 Design Year under Alterative 1 during the
weekday AM, weekday PM, and Saturday midday peak hours. All analysis worksheets are
provided in the Appendix. Although Alternative 1 (Geometric Improvements and Access
Management) is expected to improve safety at the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road
intersection, operational deficiencies will remain.


Alternative 2 ­ Roundabout

The second improvement alternative evaluated for the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road
intersection consisted of reconstructing the intersection to create a modern roundabout. A
roundabout is a circular intersection with design features that promote safe and efficient traffic
flow. Vehicles travel counterclockwise around a raised center island with entering traffic
yielding the right-of-way to circulating traffic. Motorists approaching a roundabout reduce their


3   Cottrell, B.H. Jr.; The Development of Criteria for the Treatment of Right Turn Movements on Rural Roads; 2001.
4    A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets; American Association of State Highway and
    Transportation Officials (AASHTO); 2004.


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                               Page 22
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




speeds due to the geometric curvature, look for potential conflicts with vehicles already in the
roundabout, and should be prepared to stop for pedestrians and bicyclists. Once in the
roundabout, vehicles maintain low speeds due to deflection of traffic around the center island as
motorists proceed to the appropriate exit.

In addition and consistent with Alternative 1, it is recommended that the southwestern-most
driveway for 159 Portsmouth Avenue located within ±50 feet of the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt
Road intersection be closed and the northeastern-most driveway be maintained for motorists
destined to or originating from 159 Portsmouth Avenue to be consistent with good access
management practices. A conceptual roadway sketch for this alternative is included on Figure 9.

As shown in Table 8, capacity and queue analyses were conducted at the NH Route 33 and
Winnicutt Road intersection for the 2030 Design Year under Alterative 2 during the
weekday AM, weekday PM, and Saturday midday peak hours. All analysis worksheets are
provided in the Appendix.

Intersections that may not be appropriate locations for roundabouts, however, could include
those with topographic or right-of-way constraints that limit the ability to provide appropriate
geometry, those with highly unbalanced traffic flows, and isolated intersections in a series of
signalized intersections. Due to the limited right-of-way at the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road
intersection and the highly unbalanced traffic flows on NH Route 33 versus Winnicutt Road, a
roundabout design may not be the most feasible design alternative.


Alternative 3 ­ Traffic Signal

The third improvement alternative evaluated for the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road
intersection consisted of installing a fully-actuated traffic control signal. Unsignalized
intersections introduce potential safety conditions that do not exist at signalized intersections
because of the priority of movements along the main roadway. When vehicles stop or slow down
to turn from the mainline, speed differentials are created between vehicles traveling in the same
direction. Although the installation of a traffic signal can increase the frequency of rear-end
collisions, the crashes are less severe than at unsignalized intersections.

In addition, consideration should be given to closing the northeastern-most driveway for
159 Portsmouth Avenue and placing the southwestern-most driveway within the traffic signal.
To accommodate the traffic volumes along NH Route 33 when placed under traffic signal
control, it is recommended that the NH Route 33 northbound approach be widened to provide a
through lane and a shared through/right-turn lane. Due to the volume of traffic along
NH Route 33, it is recommended that exclusive left-turn lanes be provided along NH Route 33
northbound and southbound for turns onto Winnicutt Road and into the 159 Portsmouth Avenue
driveway. A conceptual roadway sketch for this alternative is included on Figure 10.


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                               Page 23
      PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
      Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




      As shown in Table 8, capacity and queue analyses were conducted at the NH Route 33 and
      Winnicutt Road intersection for the 2030 Design Year under Alterative 3 during the
      weekday AM, weekday PM, and Saturday midday peak hours. All analysis worksheets are
      provided in the Appendix. The traffic signal alternative for the NH Route 33 and Winnicutt Road
      intersection is the preferred option as it improves operations, accommodates future traffic-
      volume projections, and provides safety for vehicles, pedestrians, and the nearby Fire Station.

STRATHAM TRAFFIC CIRCLE


Based on field observations and inventories, several areas for safety concern were noted. The
Stratham Traffic Circle entering roadways are under free-flow control while the internal


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                                             Page 25
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




circulating movements are under YIELD-sign control. The location of the YIELD signs on the
internal circulating movements is in contrast to standard rotaries or roundabouts where the
entering maneuvers are under YIELD-sign control. Additional areas of concern were noted as
follows:


      ·      Northern Section ­ NH Route 33 Westbound and NH Route 108 Northbound:
             ¾ There are between 226 and 619 vehicles per hour within the Stratham Traffic Circle
               (NH Route 108 northbound) that are destined for NH Route 108 to the north.
             ¾ These vehicles currently experience long delays as they are under YIELD-sign
               control and are required to merge and weave with 543 to 727 vehicles per hour to
               reach their exiting point onto NH Route 108 northbound.
             ¾ The capacity constraints on this approach are expected to be exacerbated with the
               addition of historical traffic growth.

      ·      Western Section ­ NH Route 108 Southbound and NH Route 33 Westbound:
             ¾ There are between 501 and 672 vehicles per hour within the Stratham Traffic Circle
               (NH Route 33 westbound) that are destined for NH Route 108 to the south.
             ¾ These vehicles currently experience long delays as they are under YIELD-sign
               control and are required to merge and weave with 366 to 564 vehicles per hour to
               reach their exiting point onto NH Route 108 southbound.
             ¾ The capacity constraints on this approach are expected to be exacerbated with the
               addition of historical traffic growth.
             ¾ Within the weaving section, the distance between the entry gore and the exit gore is
               only ±180 feet. This short distance increases the intensity of lane changing and causes
               more delay on the Stratham Traffic Circle internal approach.
             ¾ Safety is further impacted as motorists on Stratham Traffic Circle internal approach
               are required to look behind them, over their right shoulder for an acceptable gap in
               the NH Route 108 southbound traffic stream.

      ·      Eastern Section ­ NH Route 108 Northbound and NH Route 33 Eastbound:
             ¾ The NH Route 108 northbound approach enters into the Stratham Traffic Circle under
               free-flow conditions in two travel lanes that diverge with one lane exiting the
               Stratham Traffic Circle onto NH Route 33 eastbound and one lane continuing to
               circulate within the Stratham Traffic Circle.




10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                    Page 26
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




             ¾ Some vehicles within the Stratham Traffic Circle (NH Route 33 eastbound)
               approaching the intersection were observed to continue into the intersection without
               yielding to oncoming NH Route 108 northbound vehicles.
             ¾ It appeared as though some vehicles within the Stratham Traffic Circle (NH Route 33
               eastbound) entered the merge and weave area under the incorrect assumption that
               they could proceed unimpeded within a dedicated travel lane (the NH Route 108
               northbound inside travel lane).

The following improvement measures are intended to address safety and intersection capacity
needs as well as maintain the historic character of the Town Center District by improving
pedestrian and bicycle mobility, balanced with improving vehicular operations.


Alternative 1 ­ NH Route 108 Mainline with Traffic Signal

The first improvement alternative evaluated for the Stratham Traffic Circle was to reconfigure
the western portion to provide two-way traffic flow along NH Route 108 and serve as the
mainline for vehicular progression. The eastern section would provide two-way traffic flow,
serve as a `downtown area' for vehicles, pedestrians, and bicycles to access a park area, and
maintain access for the existing uses along this section of roadway (i.e., 132, 140, and
142 Portsmouth Avenue). The northern section would provide two-way traffic flow for
NH Route 33 vehicles to access or egress NH Route 108.

At the southern end of the Stratham Traffic Circle, the Downtown Area access roadway would
intersect NH Route 108 at an unsignalized intersection and would allow right-turns in and right-
turns out only. At the northwestern end of the Stratham Traffic Circle, a fully-actuated traffic
signal would be installed at the intersection of NH Route 108 and NH Route 33. At the
northeastern end of the Stratham Traffic Circle, a roundabout would be constructed that would
connect NH Route 33 with the northern end of the Downtown Area access roadway and
potentially the driveway for 137 and 139 Portsmouth Avenue. A conceptual roadway sketch for
this alternative is included on Figure 11.

As shown in Table 9, capacity and queue analyses were conducted at the three locations for the
2030 Design Year under Alterative 1 during the weekday AM, weekday PM, and Saturday
midday peak hours. All analysis worksheets are provided in the Appendix.

Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire




Alternative 2 ­ NH Route 108 Mainline with Roundabout

The second improvement alternative evaluated for the Stratham Traffic Circle was similar to
Alternative 1 by reconfiguring the western portion to provide two-way traffic flow along
NH Route 108 and serve as the mainline for vehicular progression. Although the eastern section
would provide two-way traffic flow, serve as a `downtown area' for vehicles, pedestrians, and
bicycles to access a park area, and maintain access for the existing uses along this section of
Portsmouth Avenue, the Downtown Area access roadway would only provide access at the
northeastern end of the Stratham Traffic Circle. The elimination of the southern connection
would be to prevent vehicles from cutting through the Downtown Area access roadway from
NH Route 108 south to NH Route 33. The northern section would provide two-way traffic flow
for NH Route 33 vehicles to access or egress NH Route 108.

At the northwestern end of the Stratham Traffic Circle, a roundabout would be constructed that
would connect NH Route 108 south, NH Route 108 north, and NH Route 33. At the northeastern
end of the Stratham Traffic Circle, a potential fully-actuated traffic signal would be installed at
the intersection of NH Route 33 with the Downtown Area access roadway and the driveway for
137 and 139 Portsmouth Avenue. A conceptual roadway sketch for this alternative is included on
Figure 12.

As shown in Table 10, capacity and queue analyses were conducted at the NH Route 33 and
NH Route 108 intersections for the 2030 Design Year under Alterative 2 during the
weekday AM, weekday PM, and Saturday midday peak hours. All analysis worksheets are
provided in the Appendix.

Alternative 3 ­ NH Route 108 South and NH Route 33 Mainline with Roundabout

The third improvement alternative evaluated for the Stratham Traffic Circle was to reconfigure
the eastern portion to provide two-way traffic flow and serve as the mainline for vehicular
progression between NH Route 108 south and NH Route 33. The eastern section would provide
two-way traffic flow, serve as a `downtown area' for vehicles, pedestrians, and bicycles to
access a park area, and maintain access for the existing uses along this section of roadway (i.e.,
127, 129, and 131 Portsmouth Avenue). The northern section would provide two-way traffic
flow for NH Route 33 vehicles to access or egress NH Route 108.

At the southern and northwestern ends of the Stratham Traffic Circle, the Downtown Area access
roadway would intersect NH Route 108 at unsignalized intersections and would restrict left-turns
onto NH Route 108 northbound. At the northeastern end of the Stratham Traffic Circle, a
roundabout would be constructed that would connect NH Route 33 with NH Route 108. A
conceptual roadway sketch for this alternative is included on Figure 13.


10550 Preliminary Design Report 102510.doc                                                                             Page 32
PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT ­ TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTION AND IMPACT ANALYSIS
Stratham Town Center District ­ Stratham, New Hampshire

2030 Design Year under Alterative 3 during the weekday AM, weekday PM, and Saturday
midday peak hours. All analysis worksheets are provided in the Appendix.
